datafield.subfield: Master equations and the theory of stochastic path integrals

This review provides a pedagogic and self-contained introduction to master equations and to their representation by path integrals. Since the 1930s, master equations have served as a fundamental tool to understand the role of fluctuations in complex biological, chemical, and physical systems. Despite their simple appearance, analyses of master equations most often rely on low-noise approximations such as the Kramers–Moyal or the system size expansion, or require ad-hoc closure schemes for the derivation of low-order moment equations. We focus on numerical and analytical methods going beyond the low-noise limit and provide a unified framework for the study of master equations. After deriving the forward and backward master equations from the Chapman–Kolmogorov equation, we show how the two master equations can be cast into either of four linear partial differential equations (PDEs). Three of these PDEs are discussed in detail. The first PDE governs the time evolution of a generalized probability generating function whose basis depends on the stochastic process under consideration. Spectral methods, WKB approximations, and a variational approach have been proposed for the analysis of the PDE. The second PDE is novel and is obeyed by a distribution that is marginalized over an initial state. It proves useful for the computation of mean extinction times. The third PDE describes the time evolution of a ‘generating functional’, which generalizes the so-called Poisson representation. Subsequently, the solutions of the PDEs are expressed in terms of two path integrals: a ‘forward’ and a ‘backward’ path integral. Combined with inverse transformations, one obtains two distinct path integral representations of the conditional probability distribution solving the master equations. We exemplify both path integrals in analysing elementary chemical reactions. Moreover, we show how a well-known path integral representation of averaged observables can be recovered from them. Upon expanding the forward and the backward path integrals around stationary paths, we then discuss and extend a recent method for the computation of rare event probabilities. Besides, we also derive path integral representations for processes with continuous state spaces whose forward and backward master equations admit Kramers–Moyal expansions. A truncation of the backward expansion at the level of a diffusion approximation recovers a classic path integral representation of the (backward) Fokker–Planck equation. One can rewrite this path integral in terms of an Onsager–Machlup function and, for purely diffusive Brownian motion, it simplifies to the path integral of Wiener. To make this review accessible to a broad community, we have used the language of probability theory rather than quantum (field) theory and do not assume any knowledge of the latter. The probabilistic structures underpinning various technical concepts, such as coherent states, the Doi-shift, and normal-ordered observables, are thereby made explicit.

Note that we do not distinguish between random variables and their outcomes. Moreover, we stick to the physicists' convention of ordering times in descending order. In the mathematical literature, the reverse order is more common, see e.g. [, 4: #ropaa5ae2bib004]

Due to the central importance of the Feynman-Kac formula, we provide a brief proof of it in appendix also encounter the formula in section, 4: #ropaa5ae2s4 in evaluating a path integral representation of the (backward) master equation

The Langevin equation corresponding to the SDE (, 4: #ropaa5ae2eqn004) reads {{\partial}_{s}}x(s)={{\alpha}_{s}}\left(x(s)\right)+\sqrt{{{\beta}_{s}}\left(x(s)\right)}\eta (s), with the Gaussian white noise \eta (s) having zero mean and the auto-correlation function \langle \eta (s)\eta \left({{s}^{\prime}}\right)\rangle =\delta \left(s-{{s}^{\prime}}\right)

Just as a population whose growth is described by the deterministic equation {{\partial}_{\tau}}n={{n}^{2}} explodes after a finite time, so does a population whose growth is described by the master equation (, 11: #ropaa5ae2eqn011) with transition rate w(n,m)={{\delta}_{n,m+1}}m(m-1) [, 117: #ropaa5ae2bib117]. This transition rate models the elementary reaction 2\,A\to 3\,A as explained in section, 1.5: #ropaa5ae2s1-5. An explosion also occurs for the rate w(n,m)={{\delta}_{n,m+1}}{{m}^{2}}
As before, sums whose range is not specified cover the whole state space

Later, in our derivation of the forward path integral in section, 5.1: #ropaa5ae2s5-1, we employ the finite difference approximation \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&\begin{array}{*{35}{l}} \underset{ \Delta t\to 0}{{\lim}}\,\left(|g(\tau + \Delta t|\centerdot )\rangle \,-\,|g(\tau |\centerdot )\rangle \right)/ \Delta t=\underset{ \Delta t\to 0}{{\lim}}\,{{\tilde{{\mathcal{Q}}}\,}_{\tau, \Delta t}}|g(\tau |\centerdot )\rangle. \end{array}\end{eqnarray} \end{align*} \end{equation*} This scheme conforms with the derivation of the forward master equation (, 10: #ropaa5ae2eqn010)

Use {{\left({{\partial}_{q}}\,+\,\zeta \tilde{{x}}\,\right)}^{n}}f(q){{|}_{q=-\tilde{{q}}\,/\zeta}}=\partial _{q}^{n}\left({{\text{e}}^{\tilde{{x}}\,\left(\zeta q+\tilde{{q}}\,\right)}}f(q)\right){{|}_{q=-\tilde{{q}}\,/\zeta}} and the analyticity of {{\text{e}}^{\tilde{x}\left(\zeta q+\tilde{q}\right)}}f(q) for an analytic test function f

In the derivation of the backward path integral in section, 4.1: #ropaa5ae2s4-1, we use the finite difference approximation \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&\begin{array}{*{35}{l}} \underset{ \Delta t\to 0}{{\lim}}\,\left(|\,p(\centerdot |\tau - \Delta t)\rangle \,-|\,p(\centerdot |\tau )\rangle \right)/ \Delta t=\underset{ \Delta t\to 0}{{\lim}}\,\tilde{{\mathcal{Q}}}\,_{\tau - \Delta t, \Delta t}^{\dagger}|\,p(\centerdot |\tau )\rangle. \end{array}\end{eqnarray} \end{align*} \end{equation*} The discretization scheme conforms with the derivation of the backward master equation (, 12: #ropaa5ae2eqn012)

This discretization of time conforms with the Itô prescription for forward-time SDEs and with the derivation of the backward master equation (, 12: #ropaa5ae2eqn012) (see section, 4.3: #ropaa5ae2s4-3 and also the footnote on page 25)

With {{{\mathsf {N}}}_{\boldsymbol{r}}} denoting the neighbouring lattice site of \boldsymbol{r}\in {{\left(l\mathbb{Z}\right)}^{d}}, the ordinary Laplace operator follows as the limit of a finite-difference approximation, i.e. as \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&\underset{\boldsymbol{r}^{{\prime}}\in {{{\mathsf {N}}}_{\boldsymbol{r}}}}{\sum}\,\frac{{{f}_{\boldsymbol{r}^{{\prime}}}}-{{f}_{\boldsymbol{r}}}}{{{l}^{2}}}\to \underset{i=1}{\overset{d}{\sum}}\,\partial _{{{r}_{i}}}^{2}\,f\left(\boldsymbol{r}\right)= \Delta f\left(\boldsymbol{r}\right).\end{eqnarray} \end{align*} \tag{ 223 } \end{equation*}

If Hamilton's equations are fulfilled, it holds that \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}\begin{array}{*{35}{l}} {{\tilde{{\mathcal{Q}}}\,}_{\tau}}\left(\Delta q,\text{i} \Delta x\right) & =\left({{\mathcal{Q}}_{\tau}}\left(\tilde{{q}}\,,\tilde{{x}}\,\right)+\frac{\partial {{\mathcal{Q}}_{\tau}}}{\partial \tilde{{q}}\,}\zeta \Delta q+\frac{\partial {{\mathcal{Q}}_{\tau}}}{\partial \tilde{{x}}\,}{{\zeta}^{-1}}\text{i} \Delta x+ \Delta {{\mathcal{Q}}_{\tau}}\right) \\ \,\,\, & \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,+\,\,\left(\left({{\partial}_{\tau}}\tilde{{q}}\,\right){{\zeta}^{-1}}\text{i} \Delta x-\left({{\partial}_{\tau}}\tilde{{x}}\,\right)\left(\zeta \Delta q+\tilde{{q}}\,\right)\right) \\ {} & =-{{\partial}_{\tau}}\left(\tilde{{x}}\,\tilde{{q}}\,\right)-\left(\tilde{{x}}\,{{\partial}_{-\tau}}\tilde{{q}}\,-{{\mathcal{Q}}_{\tau}}\left(\tilde{{q}}\,,\tilde{{x}}\,\right)\right)+ \Delta {{\mathcal{Q}}_{\tau}}. \end{array}\end{eqnarray} \end{align*} \end{equation*} Here, \Delta {{\mathcal{Q}}_{\tau}} represents all terms of the Taylor expansion of {{\mathcal{Q}}_{\tau}} that are of second or higher order in the deviations
